editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.head: Scaena prima

sp.speaker: Malfort.
sp.l: And as I told you sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I understand you,
Clarinda's still perverse.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: She's worse, obdurate,
Flinty relentless, my love-passions jeered at,
My presents scorned.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Tis strange a waiting-woman,
In her condition apt to yield, should hold out,
A man of your place, reverend beard and shape,
Besieging her.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You might add too my wealth,
Which she contemns, five hundred crowns per annum,
For which I have ventured hard, my conscience knows it,
Not thought upon, though offered for a jointure:
This chain which my lords peasants worship, stouted;
My solemn hums and has, the servants quake at,
No rhetoric with her; every hour she hangs out
Some new flag of defiance to torment me:
Last lent my lady called me her poor John,
But now I am grown a walking skeleton,
You may see through and through me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Indeed you are much fallen away.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: I am a kind of nothing,
As she hath made me: love's a terrible glister,
And if some cordial of her favours help not,
I shall like an Italian die backward,
And breathe my last the wrong way.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: As I live you have my pity; but this is cold comfort,
And in a friend lip-physic; and now I think on't,
I should do more, and will, so you deny not
Yourself the means of comfort.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: I'll be hanged first: one dram of't I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You are not jealous of any man's access to her?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I would not receive the dor, but as a bosom friend
You shall direct me, still provided that
I understand who is the man, and what
His purpose that pleads for me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: By all means.
First, for the undertaker I am he:
The means that I will practise, thus —

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Pray you forward,

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You know your lady chaste Caliste loves her.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Too well, that makes her proud.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Nay, give me leave.
This beauteous lady, I may style her so,
(Being the paragon of France for feature)
Is not alone contented in herself
To seem, and be good, but desires to make
All such as have dependence on her like her;
For this Clarinda's liberty is restrained;
And though her kinsman the gate's shut against me;
Now if you please to make yourself the door,
For my conveyance to her, though you run
The hazard of a check for't, 'tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: It being for mine own ends.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I'll give it o'er,
If that you make the least doubt otherwise:
Studying upon't? good morrow.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Pray you stay sir;
You are my friend: yet as the proverb says,
When love puts in, friendship is gone: suppose
You should yourself affect her?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Do you think I'll commit incest; for it is no less,
She being my cousin germane. Fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: I had forgotten that; for this once forgive me.
Only to ease the throbbing of my heart,
(For I do feel strange pangs) instruct me what
You will say for me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: First, I'll tell her that
She hath so far besotted you, that you have
Almost forgotten to cast account.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Mere truth sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: That of a wise and provident steward,
You are turned stark ass.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Urge that point home, I am so.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: That you adore the ground she treads upon,
And kiss her footsteps.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: As I do when I find their print in the snow.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: A loving fool I know it,
By your bloodless-frosty lips: then having related
How much you suffer for her, and how well
You do deserve it —

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: How? to suffer?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No sir, to have your love returned.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: That's good, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I will deliver her an inventory
Of your good parts: as this your precious nose,
Dropping affection: your high-forehead, reaching
Almost to the crown of your head; your slender waste,
And a back not like a thresher's, but a bending
And courtlike back, and so forth, for your body.
But when I touch your mind, for that must take her,
(Since your outside promises little) I'll enlarge it,
(Though never so narrow) as your arts to thrive,
Your composition with the cook, and butler,
Fory coney-skins and chippings, and half a share
With all the under-officers of the house,
In stranger's bounties, that she shall have all,
And you as 'twere her bailiff.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: As I will be.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: As you shall, so I'll promise. Then your qualities.
As playing on a gittern, or Jew's trump.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: A little too on the vial.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I care you nothing.
Then singing her asleep with curious catches
Of your own making: for as I have heard,
You are poetical.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Something given that way.
Yet my works seldom thrive: and the main reason
The poets urge for't, is, because I am not
As poor as they are.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Very likely: fetch her,
While I am in the vain.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'Tis an apt time, my lady being at her prayers.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Let her pray on.
Nay go, and if upon my intercession
She do you not some favour, I'll disclaim her;
I'll ruminate on't the while.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: A hundred crowns is your reward.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Without 'em — nay, no trifling. Ex. Malf.
That this dull clod of ignorance should know
How to get money, yet want eyes to see
How grossly he's abused, and wrought upon,
When he should make his will, the rogues turned rampant,
As he had renewed his youth: a handsome wench
Love one a spittle-whore would run away from?
Well master steward, I will plead for you
In such a method, as it shall appear
You are fit to be a property.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yonder he walks
That knows my worth and value, though you scorn it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: If my lady know not this —

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I'll answer it:
If you were a nun, I hope your cousin german
Might talk with you through a grate, but you are none,
And therefore may come closer: never hang off,
As I live you shall bill: you may salute as strangers,
Custom allows it. Now, now, come upon her
With all your oratory, tickle her to the quick,
As a young advocate should, and leave no virtue
Of mine unmentioned, I'll stand sentinel;
Nay keep the door myself. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How have you worked
This piece of motley to your ends?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Of that at leisure, mistress. Kissing.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Lower, you are too loud,
Though the fool be deaf some of the house may hear you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Suppose they should, I am a gentleman,
And held your kinsman, under that I hope
I may be free.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I grant it, but with caution;
But be not seen to talk with me familiarly,
But at fit distance, or not seen at all,
It were the better: you know my lady's humour,
She is all honour, and composed of goodness,
(As she pretends) and you having no business,
How jealous may she grow?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I will be ruled.
But you have promised, and I must enjoy you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: We shall find time for that; you are too hasty:
Make yourself fit, and I shall make occasion,
Deliberation makes best in that business,
And contents every way.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: But you must feed
This foolish steward with some shadow of
A future favour, that we may preserve him
To be our instrument.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Hang him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: For my sake sweet,
I undertook to speak for him, any bauble,
Or slight employment in the way of service,
Will feed him fat.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Leave him to me,Enter Malfort.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: She comes. My lady.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I will satisfy her.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: How far have you prevailed?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Observe.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Monsieur Malfort.
I must be brief, my cousin hath spoken much
In your behalf, and to give you some proof,
I entertain you as my servant,
You shall have the grace.

sp.speaker: Leon
sp.l: Upon your knee receive it,

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: And take it a special favour from me,
To tie my shoe.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: I am o'erjoyed.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Good reason.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You may come higher in time.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No more, the lady. Enter Calista.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: She frowns.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I thank you for this visit cousin,
But without leave hereafter from my lady,
I dare not change discourse with you.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Pray you take your morning's draught.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I thank you:Exeunt Leon. Malfort.
Happiness attend your honour.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.l: Who gave warrant to this private parley?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: My innocence; I hope
My conference with a kinsman cannot call
Your anger on me.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.l: Kinsman? Let me have
No more of this, as you desire you may continue mine.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Why madam (Under pardon)
Suppose him otherwise: yet coming in
A lawful way it is excusable.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I grant you are made of pureness,
And that your tenderness of honour holds
The sovereignty o'er your passions. Yet you have
A noble husband, with allowed embraces,
To quench lascivious fires, should such flame in you,
As I must never believe. Were I the wife
Of one that could but zany brave Cleander,
Even in his least perfections, (Excuse
My o'erbold inference) I should desire
To meet no other object.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You grow saucy. Do I look further?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: No, dear madam: and
It is my wonder or astonishment rather,
You could deny the service of Lisander;
A man without a rival: one the King
And kingdom gazes on with admiration,
For all the excellencies a mother could
Wish in her only son.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Did not mine honour
And obligation to Cleander, force me
To be deaf to his complaints?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis true; but yet
Your rigor to command him from your presence,
Argued but small compassion; the groves
Witness his grievous sufferings, your fair name
Upon the rind of every gentle poplar,
And amorous myrtle, (Trees to Venus sacred)
With adoration carved, and kneeled unto,
This you (Unseen of him) both saw and heard
Without compassion, and what received he
For his true sorrows? but the heavy knowledge,
That 'twas your peremptory will and pleasure,
( howe'er my lord lived in him) he should quit
Your sight and house for ever.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I confess I gave him a strong potion to work
Upon his hot blood, and I hope 'twill cure him:
Yet I could wish the cause had concerned others,
I might have met his sorrows with more pity;
At least have lent some counsel to his miseries,
Though now for honour's sake, I must forget him,
And never know the name more of Lisander:
Yet in my justice I am bound to grant him,
(Laying his love aside) most truly noble.
But mention him no more, this instant hour
My brother Lydian, new returned from travail,
And his brave friend Clarange, long since rivals
For fair and rich Olinda, are to hear
Her absolute determination, whom
She pleases to elect: see all things ready
To entertain 'em: and on my displeasure
No more words of Lisander.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: She endures to hear him named by no tongue but her own:
Howe'er she carries it, I know she loves him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hard nature: hard condition of poor women!
That where we are most sued too, we must fly most.
The trees grow up, and mix together freely,
The oak not envious of the sailing Cedart
The lusty vine not jealous of the ivy
Because she clips the elm; the flowers shoot up,
And wantonly kiss one another hourly,
This blossom glorying in the others beauty,
And yet they smell as sweet, and look as lovely:
But we are tied to grow alone. O honour,
Thou hard law to our lives, chain to our freedoms;
He that invented thee had many curses;
How is my soul divided? O Cleander,
My best deserving husband! O Lisander!
The truest lover that e'er sacrificed
To Cupid against Hymen: oh mine honour;
A tyrant, yet to be obeyed, and 'tis
But justice we should thy strict laws endure,
Since our obedience to thee keeps us pure. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: How insupportable the difference
Of dear friends is, the sorrow that I feel
For my Lisander's absence, one that stamps
A reverend print on friendship, does assure me
You are rivals for a lady, a fair lady,
And in the acquisition of her favours,
Hazard the cutting of that Gordian knot
From your first childhood to this present hour,
By all the ties of love and amity fastened,
I am blessed in a wife (Heaven make me thankful)
Inferior to none (Sans pride I speak it)
Yet if I were a freeman, and could purchase
At any rate the certainty to enjoy
Lisander's conversation while I lived,
Forgive me my Caliste and the sex,
I never would seek change.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: My lord and brother,
I dare not blame your choice, Lisander's worth,
Being a mistress to be ever courted;
Nor shall our equal suit to fair Olinda
Weaken, but add strength to our true affection,
With zeal so long continued.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: When we know
Whom she prefers, as she can choose but one,
By our so long tried friendship we have vowed
The other shall desist.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: 'Tis yet your purpose,
But how this resolution will hold
In him that is refused, is not alone
Doubtful, but dangerous.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: The rich heir is come sir.

sp.speaker: Cleand.
sp.l: Madam Olinda.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Yes sir, and makes choice,
After some little conference with my lady,
Of this room to give answer to her suitors.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Already both look pale, between your hopes
To win the prize, and your despair to lose
What you contended for.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: No sir, I am armed.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I confident of my interest.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I'll believe ye when you have endured the test.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Is not your garter
Untied? you promised that I should grow higher
In doing you service.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Fall off or you lose me. Exit Malf.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Nay take your place, no Paris now sits judge
On the contending goddesses. You are
The deity that must make cursed or happy,
One of your languishing servants.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I thus look with equal eyes on both, either deserves
A fairer fortune than they can in reason
Hope for from me; from Lydian I expect,
When I have made him mine, all pleasures that
The sweetness of his manners, youth, and virtues
Can give assurance of: but turning this way
To brave Clarange, in his face appears
A kind of majesty which should command,
Not sue for favour. If the fairest lady
Of France, set forth with nature's best endowments
Nay should I add a Princess of the blood,
Did now lay claim to either for a husband,
So vehement my affection is to both,
My envy at her happiness would kill me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The strangest love I ever heard.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You can enjoy but one.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The more I say the merrier.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Witness these tears I love both, as I know
You burn with equal flames, and so affect me;
Abundance makes me poor; such is the hard
Condition of my fortune; be your own judges;
If I should favour both, 'twill taint my honour,
And that before my life I must prefer,
If one I lean to, the other is disvalued;
You are fiery both, and love will make you warmer,

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The warmer still the fitter. You are a fool lady.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: To what may love, and the devil jealousy spur you
Is too apparent: my name's called in question:
Your swords fly out, your angers range at large:
Then what a murder of my modesty follows?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Take heed of that by any means: oh innocent,
That will deny a blessing when 'tis offered,
Would I were murdered so, I would thank my modesty.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What pause you on?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: It is at length resolved.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: We are on the rack, uncertain expectation,
The greatest torture.

sp.speaker: Lidian.
sp.l: Command what you please,
And you shall see how willingly we will execute.

sp.speaker: Olinda
sp.l: Then hear what for your satisfaction,
And to preserve your friendship I resolve
Against myself, and 'tis not to be altered:
You are both brave gentlemen, I'll still profess it,
Both noble servants, for whose gentle offers,
The undeserving, and the poor Olinda
Is ever bound; you love both, fair, and virtuously;
Would I could be so happy to content both:
Which since I cannot, take this resolute answer;
Go from me both contentedly, and he
That last makes his return, and comes to visit,
Comes to my bed. You know my will: farewell;
My heart's too big to utter more: come friend.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I'll wait on you to your coach.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: You both look blank, I cannot blame you.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: We have our dispatches.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I'll home.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: And I'll abroad again, farewell. Exit Clarange and Lydian.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Farewell to ye.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Their blunted departure troubles me: I fear
A sudden and a dangerous division
Of their long love will follow: have you took
Your leave of fair Olinda? Enter Caliste with a purse.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: She is gone sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Had you brought news Lisander were returned too,
I were most happy.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Still upon Lisander?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I know he loves me, as he loves his health:
And heaven knows I love him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I find it so:
For me you have forgotten, and what I am to you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: O think not so if you had lost a sister,
You locked all your delights in, it would grieve you:
A little you would wander from the fondness,
You owed your husband: I have lost a friend,
A noble friend, all that was excellent
In man, or mankind, was contained within him.
That lost my wife —

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Madam, your noble father —
A fee for my good news.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why? what of him sir?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Is lighted at the door, and longs to see you.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.l: Attend him hither.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: O my dear Lisander.
But I'll be merry: let's meet him my Caliste.

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.l: I hope Lasander's love will now be buried:
My father will bring joy enough for one month,
To put him out of his memory.

div.stage: Enter Dorilaus, his arm in a scarf.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How do you son?
Bless my fair child, I am come to visit ye,
To see what house you keep, they say you are bountiful,
I like the noise well, and I come to try it.
Never a great belly yet? how have you trifled?
If I had done so (Son) I should have heard on't
On both sides by saint Denis.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: You are nobly welcome sir:
We have time enough for that.

sp.speaker: Dorilaus.
sp.l: See how she blushes:
'Tis a good sign you'll mend your fault, how dost thou,
My good Caliste?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Well, now I see you sir;
I hope you bring a fruitfulness along with ye.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Good luck, I never miss, I was ever good at it:
Your mother groaned for't wench, so did some other,
But I durst never tell.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How does your arm sir?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Have you been let blood of late?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Against my will sir.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: A fall dear father?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No, a gun, dear daughter;
Two or three guns; I have one herein my buttock,
'Twould trouble a surgeon's teeth to pull it out.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O me! O me!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nay, if you fall to fainting,
'Tis time for me to trudge: art such a coward,
At the mere name of hurt to change thy colour?
I have been shot that men might see clean through me
And yet I fainted not: besides myself,
Here are an hospital of hurt men for ye.

div.stage: Enter servants wounded in several places.

sp.speaker: Cloan.
sp.l: What should this wonder be?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am amazed at it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What think ye of these? they are every one hurt soundly,
Hurt to the proof, they are through, and through I assure ye;
And that's good game, they scorn your puling scratches.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Who did this sir?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Leave crying, and I'll tell you,
And get your plasters, and your warm stupes ready:
Have you never a shepherd that can tarre us over?
'Twill prove a business else, we are so many.
Coming to see you, I was set upon,
I and my men, as we were singing frolickly,
Not dreaming of an ambush of base rogues,
Set on ith' forest, I have forgotten the name —

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Betwixt this, and Fountaine-bleiu?
In the wild forest?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The same, the same, in that accursed forest,
Set on by villains, that make boot of all men.
The peers of France are pillage there, they shot at us,
Hurt us, unhorsed us, came to the sword, there plied us,
Oppressed us with fresh multitudes, fresh shot still,
Rogues that would hang themselves for a fresh doublet,
And for a scarlet cassock kill their fathers.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Lighted you among these?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Among these murderers,
Our poor bloods were engaged: yet we struck bravely,
And more than once or twice we made them shun us,
And shrink their rugged heads: but we were hurt all.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: How came you off? for I even long to hear that.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: After our prayers made to heaven to help us,
Or to be merciful unto our souls,
So near we were. Alas poor wench, wipe, wipe.
See heaven sends remedy.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am glad 'tis come sir,
My heart was even a bleeding in my body.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A curled hair gentleman stepped in, a stranger,
As he rod by, belike he heard our bickering,
Saw our distresses, drew his sword, and proved
He came to execute, and not to argue.
Lord what a lightning methought flew about him,
When he once tossed his blade; in face Adonis,
While peace inhabited between his eyebrows:
But when his noble anger stirred his mettle,
And blew his fiery parts into a flame,
Like Pallas, when she sits between two armies,
Viewing with horrid brows their sad events,
Such then he looked: and as her shield had armed him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: This man sir were a friend to give an age for.
This gentleman I must love naturally:
Nothing can keep me off; I pray you go on sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I will, for now you please me: this brave youth,
This bud of Mars, for yet he is no riper,
When once he had drawn blood, and fleshed his sword,
Fitted his manly mettle to his spirit,
How he bestirred him? what a lane he made?
And through their fiery bullets thrust securely:
The hardened villains wondering at his confidence,
Lame as I was I followed, and admired too,
And stirred, and laid about me with new spirit,
My men too with new hearts thrust into action,
And down the rogues went.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I am struck with wonder.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Remember but the story of strong Hector,
When like to lightning he broke through his vanguard,
How the Greeks frighted ran away by troops,
And trod down troops to save their lives: so this man,
Dispersed these slaves: had they been more and mightier,
He had come off the greater, and more wonder.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Where is the man, good sir, that we may honour him?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: That we may fall in superstition to him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I know not that, from me he late departed,
But not without that pious care to see safe
Me, and my weak men lodged, and dressed; I urged him
First hither, that I might more freely thank him:
He told me he had business craved my pardon,
Business of much import.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Know you his name?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That he denied me too: a vow had barred him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: In that he was not noble to be nameless.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Daughter you must remember him when I am dead,
And in a noble sort requite his piety,
'Twas his desire to dedicate this service
To your fair thoughts.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He knows me then?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I named you,
And named you mine: I think that's all his knowledge.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: No name, no being?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Now I am mad to know him:
Saving mine honour, any thing I had now
But to enjoy his sight, but his bare picture;
Make me his saint, I must needs honour him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I know his name.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: There's thy reward for't; speak it.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: His man told me, but he desired my silence.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O Jasper speak, 'tis thy good master's cause too:
We all are bound ingratitude to compel thee.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Lisander, yes, I am sure it was Lisander.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Lisander? 'twas Lisander.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: 'Tis Lisander. O my base thoughts? my wicked?
To make question this act could be another man's:
'Tis Lisander, a handsome timbered man.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: My Lisander! was this friend's absence to be mourned?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I grant it:
I'll mourn his going now, and mourn it seriously:
When you weep for him, sir, I'll bear you company.
That so much honour, so much honesty
Should be in one man, to do things thus bravely,
Make me his saint, to me give this brave service:
What may I do to recompense his goodness?
I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Come sir, I know you are sickly, so are your men.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I must confess I am weak,
And fitter for a bed then long discourses.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You shall hear tomorrow, tomorrow provide surgeons.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Lisander —

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: What new fire is this? Lisander — exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Prithee good Lancelot remember that
Thy master's life is in thy trust, and therefore
Be very careful.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: I will lose mine own, rather than hazard yours.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Take what disguise
You in your own discretion shall think fittest,
To keep yourself unknown.

sp.speaker: * Lanc.
sp.l: I warrant ye;
'Tis not the first time I have gone invisible:
I am as fine a fairy in a business
Concerning nightwork —

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Leave your vanities:
With this purse (Which delivered,
You may spare your oratory) convey this letter to
Caliste's woman.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: 'Tis a handsome girl, mistress Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I have made her mine. You know your work.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: And if I sweat not in it,
At my return discard me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lisand.
sp.l: O Caliste! the fairest! cruelest!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: So early stirring? A good day to you.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I was viewing sir,
The site of your house, and the handsomeness about it:
Believe me it stands healthfully and sweetly.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: The house and master of it really
Are ever at your service.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I return it:
Now if you please go forward in your story
Of your dear friend and mistress.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I will tell it,
And tell it short, because 'tis breakfast time,
(And love a tedious thing to a quick stomach)
You eat not yesternight.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I shall endure sir.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Myself (And as I then delivered to you)
A gentleman of noble hope, one Lydian,
Both brought up from our infancy together,
One company, one friendship, and one exercise,
Ever affecting, one bed holding us,
One grief, and one joy parted still between us,
More than companions, twins in all our actions,
We grew up till we were men, held one heart still:
Time called us on to arms, we were one soldier,
Alike we sought our dangers and our honours,
Gloried alike one in another's nobleness:
When arms had made us fit, we were one lover,
We loved one woman, loved without division,
And wooed a long time with one fair affection;
And she, as it appears, loves us alike too.
At length considering what our love must grow to,
And covet in the end, this one was parted,
Rivals and honours make men stand at distance.
We then wooed with advantage, but were friends still,
Saluted fairly, kept the peace of love,
We could not both enjoy the lady's favour,
Without some scandal to her reputation,
We put it to her choice, this was her sentence,
To part both from her, and the last returning
Should be her lord; we obeyed, and now you know it;
And for my part, (So truly I am touched with't)
I will go far enough, and be the last too,
Or never return:

sp.speaker: Lisand.
sp.l: A sentence of much cruelty;
But mild, compared with what's pronounced on me.
Our loving youth is born to many miseries.
What is that Lydian prey ye?

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.p: Caliste's brother, if ever you have heard of that fair lady.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: I have seen her sir.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: Then you have seen a wonder.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: I do confess: of what years is this Lydian?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: About my years: there is not much between us.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: I long to know him.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: 'Tis a virtuous longing,
As many hopes hang on his noble head,
As blossoms on a bough in may, and sweet ones.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Ye are a fair story of your friend.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Of truth sir: now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: There is a gentleman
At door, would speak with you on private business.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: With me?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: He says so, and brings haste about him.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Wait on him in. Exit Serv.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: I will retire the while, to the next room.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: We shall not long disturb you. Ent. Alcidon.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Save ye sir.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: The like to you fair sir: pray you come near.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Pray you instruct me for I know you not.
With monsieur Clarange I would speak.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I am he sir:
Ye are nobly welcome; I wait your business.

sp.speaker: Alcid.
sp.l: This will inform you.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Will you please to sit down? Reads.
He shall command me sir, I'll wait upon him
Within this hour.

sp.speaker: Alcid.
sp.l: You're a noble gentleman,
Wil't please you bring a friend? we are two of us,
And pity either sir should be unfurnished.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I have none now, and the time is set so short,
'Twill not be possible.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Do me the honour:
I know you are so full of brave acquaintance,
And worthy friends, you cannot want a partner:
I would be loath to stand still sir; besides,
You know the custom, and the vantage of it,
If you come in alone.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: And I must meet it.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Send, we'll defer an hour, let us be equal:
Games won and lost on equal terms show fairest.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis to no purpose to send any whither,
Unless men be at home by revelation:
So please you breathe a while; when I have done with him
You may be exercised too: I'll trouble no man.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: They are very loud. Now what's the news?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I must leave you,
Leave you a while, two hours hence I'll return friend.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: A little business.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: An't be but a little, you may take me with ye.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Twill be a trouble to you.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: No indeed, to do you service, I account a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I must alone.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Clarang.
sp.l: 'Tis necessity —
Before you pass the walks, and back again,
I will be with ye.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: If it be not unmannerly
To press you, I would go.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: I'll tell you true sir,
This gentleman and I upon appointment,
Are going to visit a lady.

sp.speaker: Lisond.
sp.l: I am no Capuchin, why should not I go?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Take the gentleman,
Come he may see the gentlewoman too,
And be most welcome, I do beseech you take him.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: By any means, I love to see a gentlewoman,
A pretty wench too.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Well sir, we'll meet you,
And at the place: my service to the lady.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: I kiss your hand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Prithee read o'er her letter.

sp.speaker: Lisander

body.p: I know you have considered the dark sentence Olinda gave us, and that (However she disguised it) it pointed more at our swords edges then our bodies banishments; the last must enjoy her: if we retire, our youths are lost in wandering; in emulation we shall grow old men, and feeble, which is the scorn of love, and rust of honour, and so return more fit to wed our sepulchres, than the saint we aim at; let us therefore make our journey short, and our hearts ready, and with our swords in our hands put it to fortune, which shall be worthy to receive that blessing, I'll stay you on the mountain, our old hunting place, this gentleman alone runs the hazard with me, and so I kiss your hand.

sp.l: Is this your wench? you'll find her a sharp mistress.
What have I thrust myself into? is this that Lydian
You told me of?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: My lady's brother?
No cause to heave my sword against but his?
To save the father yesterday, and this morning,
To help to kill the son? this is most courteous?
The only way to make the daughter dote on me.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Why do you muse? would ye go off?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: No, no, I must on now; this will be kindly taken;
No life to sacrifice, but part of hers?
Do you fight straight?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Yes, presently.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Tomorrow then,
The baleful tidings of this day will break out,
And this night's sun will set in blood; I am troubled:
If I am killed, I am happy.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Will you go friend?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I am ready sir, fortune thou hast made me monstrous. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Your cousin, and my true friend, lusty Leon,
Shall know how you use me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Be more temperate,
Or I will never use, nor know you more
Ith' way of a servant: all the house takes notice
Of your ridiculous foppery; I have no sooner
Performed my duties in my lady's chamber,
And she scarce down the stairs, but you appear
Like my evil spirit to me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Can the fish live out of the water, or the salamander
Out of the fire? or I live warm, but in
The frying-pan of your favour?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Pray you forget
Your curious comparisons, borrowed from
The pond, and kitchen, and remember what
My lady's pleasure is forth 'Entertainment
Of her noble father.

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: I would learn the art of memory in your table book.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Very good sir, no more but up and ride, I apprehend
Your meaning, soft fire makes sweet malt sir:
I'll answer you in a proverb,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But one kiss from thy honey lip.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You sight too high, my hand is
A fair ascent from my foot, his slavering kisses
Spoil me more gloves, — enough for once, you'll surfeit
With too much grace.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Have you no employment for me?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Yes, yes, go send for Leon, and convey him
Into the private arbour, from his mouth
I hear your praises with more faith.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I am gone-yet one thing ere I go, there's at the door
The rarest fortune-teller, he hath told me
The strangest things; he knows ye are my mistress,
And under seal delivered how many children
I shall beget on you, pray you give him hearing,
He'll make it good to you.

sp.speaker: Gla.
sp.l: A cunning man
Of your own making, howsoe'er I'll hear him
At your entreaty.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Now I perceive ye love me,
At my entreaty, come in friend — remember
To speak as I directed, he knows his lesson,
And the right way to please her; this it is
To have a head-piece. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Lancelot like a fortune-teller, with a purse, and two letters in it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Tis said you can tell fortunes to come.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Yes mistress, and what's past;
Unglove your hand, by this straight line, I see
You have lain crooked.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: How? lain crooked?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Yes; and in that posture played at the old game,
( nobody hears me, and I'll be no blab)
And at it lost your maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: A shrewd fellow;
'Tis truth, but not to be confessed; in this
Your palmistry deceives you, some thing else sir.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Ye are a great woman with your lady, and
Acquainted with her counsels.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Still more strange.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: There is a noble knight Lisander loves her,
Whom she regards not ▪ and the destinies
With whom I am familiar, have delivered
That by your means alone, he must enjoy her.
Your hand again, yes, yes; you have already
Promised him your assistance, and what's more,
Tasted his bounty, for which, from the sky
There are 200. crowns dropped in a purse,
Look back, you'll find it true; nay, open it,
'Tis good gold I assure you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: How, two letters? the first endorsed to me? this to my lady?
Subscribed Lisander.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And the fortune-teller, his servant Lancelot.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: How had I lost my eyes,
That I could not know thee? not a word of the loss
Of my virginity.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: Nor who I am.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I'll use all speedy means for your dispatch,
With a welcome answer, but till you receive it,
Continue thus disguised, monsieur Malfort
(You know the way to humour him) shall provide
A lodging for you, and good entertainment;
Nay, since we trade both one way, thou shalt have
Some feeling with me, take that.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Bountiful wench mayest thou never want employment.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nor such pay boy. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Lydian, Alcidon, (At one door) Lisander, Clarange, (At another.)

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: You're welcome.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Let us do our office first,
And then make choice of a new piece of ground
To try our fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: All's fair here.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: And here, their swords are equal.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: If there be any odds in mine, we will exchange.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: We'll talk of that
When we are farther off, farewell.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Farewell friend. Ex. Lisand. and Alcid

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Come let us not be idle?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I will find you employment, fear not.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: You know sir, the cause that brings us hither

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: There needs no more discoursing,
No time, nor place for repetition now.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Let our swords argue, and I wish Clarange,
The proud Olinda saw us.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Would she did;
Whatever estimation she holds of me,
She should behold me like a man fight for her.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: 'Tis nobly said; set on love; and my fortune —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The same for me, come home brave Lydian,
'Twas manly thrust, this token to the lady,
Ye have it sir, deliver it, take breath,
I see ye bleed apace, ye shall have fair play.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: You must lie there a while, I cannot help you,

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Nay, than my fortunes gone, I know I must die:
Yet dear will I sell my love, come on both,
And use your fortunes, I expect no favour;
Weak as I am, my confidence shall meet ye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Yield up your cause and live.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: What dost thou hold me?
A recreant, that prefers life before credit?
Though I bleed hard, my honour finds no issue,
That's constant to my heart.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Have at your life then.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Hold, or I'll turn, and bend my sword against ye;
My cause Clarange too, view this brave gentleman,
That yet may live to kill you, he stands nobly,
And has as great a promise of the day
As you can tie unto yourself, he's ready,
His sword as sharp, view him with that remembrance,
That you delivered him to me Clarange:
And with those eyes, that clearness will become ye:
View him, as you reported him; survey him,
Fix on your friendship sir, I know you are noble,
And step but inward to your old affection,
Examine but that soul grew to your bosom,
And try then if your sword will bite, it cannot,
The edge will turn again, ashamed, and blunted;
Lydian, you are the pattern of fair friendship,
Exampled for your love, and imitated,
The temple of true hearts, stored with affections,
For sweetness of your spirit made a saint,
Can you decline this nobleness to anger?
To mortal anger? 'gainst the man ye love most?
Have ye the name of virtuous, not the nature?

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: I will sit down.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: And I'll sit by you Lydian.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: And I'll go on, can heaven be pleased with these things?
To see two hearts that have been twined together
Married in friendship to the world, to wonder,
Of one growth, of one nourishment, one health,
Thus mortally divorced for one weak woman?
Can love be pleased? love is a gentle spirit,
The wind that blows the April flowers, not softer;
She is drawn with doves to show her peacefulness,
Lions and bloody pards are Mars's servants;
Would ye serve love? do it with humbleness,
Without a noise, with still prayers, and soft murmurs;
Upon her altars offer your obedience,
And not your brawls; she's won with tears, not terrors:
That fire ye kindle to her deity,
Is only grateful when it blows with sighs,
And holy incense flung with white hand-innocence;
Ye wound her now; ye are too superstitious,
No sacrifice of blood, or death she longs for:

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Came he from heaven?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: He tells us truth good Lydian.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: That part of noble love which is most sweet,
And gives eternal being to fair beauty,
Honour. You hack a pieces with your swords,
And that ye fight to crown, ye kill fair credit.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Thus we embrace, no more fight, but all friendship,
And where love pleases to bestow his benefits,
Let us not argue.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Nay brave sir, come in too;
You may love also, and may hope, if he do,
And not rewarded for't, there is no justice;
Farewell friend, here let's part upon our pilgrimage,
It must be so, Cupid draws on our sorrows.
And where the lot lights —

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: I shall count it happiness,
Farewell dear friend.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: First, let's relieve the gentleman
That lies hurt in your cause, and bring him off,
And take some cure for your hurts, than I will part too,
A third unfortunate, and willing wanderer. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: My fears foresaw't would come to this.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I would your sentence had been milder.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: 'Tis past help now.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I share in your despair, and yet my hopes
Have not quite left me, since all possible means
Are practised to prevent the mischief following
Their mortal meeting, my lord is coasted one way,
My father, though his hurts forbade his travel,
Hath taken another, my brother in law Beronte,
A third, and every minute we must look for
The certain knowledge, which we must endure
With that calm patience heaven shall please to lend us.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Dead both?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Such is the rumour, and 'tis general.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: I hear my passing-bell.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am in a favour.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: They say their seconds too; but what they are,
Is not known yet, some worthy fellows certain.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Where had you knowledge?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Of the country people, 'tis spoken everywhere .

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I heard it so too;
And 'tis so common, I do half believe it,
You have lost a brother wench, he loved you well,
And might have lived to have done his country service,
But he is gone, thou feld'st untimely Lydian,
But by a valiant hand, that's some small comfort,
And took him with thee too, thou lovest brave company,
Weeping will do no good, you lost a servant,
He might have lived to have been your master lady,
But you feared that.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: Good sir, be tender to me,
The news is bad enough, you need not press it.
I loved him well, I loved 'em both.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: It seems so.
How many more have you to love so lady?
They were both fools to fight for such a fiddle;
Certain there was a dearth of noble anger,
When a slight woman was thought worth a quarrel.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Pray you think nobler.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: I'll tell thee what I think, the plague, war, famine,
Nay put in dice and drunkenness, and those
You'll grant are pretty helps, kill not so many
(I mean so many noble) as your loves do,
Rather your lewdness, I crave your mercy women.
Be not offended if I anger ye.
I am sure ye have touched me deep, I came to be merry,
And with my children, but to see one ruined
By this fell accident — are they all dead?
If they be, speak?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: What news?

div.stage: Enter Beronte, Alcidon, Clarinda, following with a letter,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What dead? ye pose me;
I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: My brother Lydian, Clarange, and their seconds.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Here is one of 'em, and sure this gentleman's alive.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: I hope so, so is your son sir, so is brave Clarange:
They fought indeed, and they were hurt sufficiently;
We were all hurt, that bred the general rumour,
But friends again all, and like friends we parted.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Herded ye of Lisander?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yes, and missed him narrowly:
He was one of the combatants, fought with this gentleman,
Second against your brother, by his wisdom
(For certainly good fortune follows him)
All was made peace, I'll tell you the rest at dinner,
For we are hungry.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: I before I eat
Must pay a vow I am sworn to; my life madam
Was at Lisander's mercy, I live by it;
And for the noble favour, he desired me
To kiss your fair hand for him, offering
This second service as a sacrifice
At the altar of your virtues.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Come, joy on all sides;
Heaven will not suffer honest men to perish.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Be proud of such a friend.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Forgive me madam,
It was a grief might have concerned you near too.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: No work of excellence but still Lisander,
Go thy ways worthy.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: We'll be merry too,
Were I to speak again, I would be wiser. ** ex. manet. Cal. Clarin. stays Calist.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Too much of this rare cordial makes me sick,
However I obey you.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Now or never is an apt time to move her, madam.

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Clari.
sp.l: Your servant, I would speak with your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why dost thou look about?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: I have private business
That none must hear but you. Lisander —

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Nay, is not here, but would entreat this favour,
Some of your balsam from your own hand given,
For he is much hurt, and that he thinks would cure him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He shall have all, my prayers too.

sp.speaker: Clarind.
sp.l: But conceive, me,
It must be from yourself immediately,
Pity so brave a gentleman should perish,
He is superstitious, and he holds your hand
Of infinite power: I would not urge this madam,
But only in a man's extremes, to help him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Let him come (Good wench) 'tis that I wish, I am happy in't,
My husband his true friend, my noble father,
The fair Olinda, all desire to see him;
He shall have many hands.

sp.speaker: Clarind.
sp.l: That he desires not,
Nor eyes, but yours to look upon his miseries,
For then he thinks 'twould be no perfect cure (Madam)
He would come private.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How can that be here?
I shall do wrong unto all those that honour him,
Besides my credit.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Dare ye not trust a hurt man?
Not strain a courtesy to save a gentleman?
To save his life that has saved all your family?
A man that comes like a poor mortified pilgrim;
Only to beg a blessing, and depart again?
He would but see you, that he thinks would cure him.
But since you find fit reasons to the contrary,
And that it cannot stand with your clear honour,
Though you best know how well he has deserved of ye:
I'll send him word back, though I grieve to do it,
Grieve at my soul, for certainly 'twill kill him,
What your will is.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Stay, I will think upon't; where is he wench?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: If you desire to see him,
Let not that trouble you, he shall be with ye,
And in that time, that no man shall suspect ye;
Your honour madam, is in your own free keeping;
Your care in me, in him all honesty;
If ye desire him not, let him pass by ye:
And all this business reckon but a dream.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Go in, and counsel me, I would fain see him,
And willingly comfort him.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: 'Tis in your power.
And if you dare trust me, you shall do it safely,
Read that, and let that tell you, how he honours you.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Clarinda, with a key, and Leon.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: This happy night. Kisses her.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Preserve this eagerness
Till we meet nearer, there is something done
Will give us opportunity.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Witty girl, the plot?

sp.speaker: Clarind,
sp.l: You shall hear that at leisure,
The whole house reels with joy at the report
Of Lidian's safety, and that joy increased
From their affection to the brave Lisander,
In being made the happy instrument to compound
The bloody difference.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: They will hear shortly that
Will turn their mirth to mourning, he was then
The principal means to save two lives, but since
There are two fallen, and by his single hand,
For which his life must answer, if the King,
Whose arm is long, can reach him.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: We have now no spare time to hear storeys, take this key,
'Twill make your passage to the banquetting house
I' the garden free.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You will not fail to come?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: For mine own sake never doubt it? now for Lisander. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Dorilaus, Cleander, servants with lights.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: To bed, to bed, 'tis very late.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: To bed all, I have drunk a health too much,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You'll sleep the better,
My usual physic that way.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Where's your mistress?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: She is above, but very ill and aguish:
The late fright of her brother, has much troubled her;
She would entreat to lie alone.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Her pleasure.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Commend my love to her, and my prayers for her health,
I'll see her ere I go. Ex. manet Clarin.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: All good rest to ye:
Now to my watch for Lisander, when he's furnished,
For mine own friend, since I stand sentinel,
I love to laugh i'th' evenings too, and may,
The privilege of my place will warrant it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: You have done well hitherto; where are we now?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Not far from the house, I hear by th'owls,
There are many of your Welsh falkoners about it;
Here were a night to choose to run away with
Another man's wife, and do the feat.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Peace knave,
The house is here before us, and some may hear us;
The candles are all out.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: But one i'the parlour,
I see it simper hither, pray come this way.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Step to the garden door, and feel and 't be open.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I am going, luck deliver me from the saw pits,
Or I am buried quick: I hear a dog,
No, 'tis a cricket, ha? here's a cuckold buried,
Take heed of his horns sir, here's the door, 'tis open.

sp.speaker: Clarinda
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Friend.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sir, Lisander?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Ye are welcome, follow me, and make no noise.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Go to your horse, and keep your watch with care, sirrah
And be sure ye sleep not. Ex. lisan. Clarin.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: Send me out the dairy-maid
To play at trump with me, and keep me waking,
My fellow horse, and I now must discourse
Like two learned almanac-makers, of the stars,
And tell what a plentiful year 'twil prove of drunkards,
If I had but a pottle of sack, like a sharp prickle,
To knock my nose against when I am nodding,
I should sing like a nightingale, but I must
Keep watch without it, I am apt to dance,
Good fortune guide me from the fairs circles. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Clarinda with a taper, and Lisander with a pistol, two chairs set out.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Come near,Caliste sitting behind a curtain.
I'll leave ye now, draw but that curtain,
And have your wish; now Leon I am for thee.
We that are servants must make use of stolen hours,
And be glad of snatched occasions. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lisand.
sp.l: She is asleep,
Fierce love hath closed his lights, I may look on her,
Within her eyes 'Has locked his graces up,
I may behold and live; how sweet she breathes?
The orient morning breaking out in odours,
Is not so full of perfumes, as her breath is;
She is the abstract of all excellence, and scorns a parallel.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Your servant, your most obedient slave (Adored lady)
That comes but to behold those eyes again,
And pay some vows I have to sacred beauty,
And so pass by; I am blind as ignorance,
And know not where I wander, how I live,
Till I receive from their bright influence
Light to direct me, for devotions sake,
You are the saint I tread these holy steps to.
And holy saints are all relenting sweetness;
Be not enraged nor be not angry with me;
The greatest attribute of heaven is mercy;
And 'tis the crown of justice, and the glory
Where it may kill with right, to save with pity.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why do you kneel, I know you come to mock me,
To upbraid me with the benefits you have given me,
Which are too many, and too mighty sir,
For my return; and I confess 'tis justice,
That for my cruelty you should despise me,
And I expect however you are calm now,
A foil you strive to set your cause upon,
It will break out; Caliste is unworthy,
Coy, proud, disdain full, I acknowledge all,
Colder of comfort than the frozen North is,
And more a stranger to Lisander's worth,
His youth and faith then it becomes her gratitude,
I blush to grant it, yet take this along,
A sovereign medicine to allay displeasure,
May be an argument to bring me off too;
She is married, and she is chaste; how sweet that sounds?
How it perfumes all air 'tis spoken in?
O dear Lisander, would you break this union?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: No, I adore it: let me kiss your hand,
And seal the fair faith of a gentleman on it.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You are truly valiant, would it not afflict you
To have the horrid name of coward touch you?
Such is the whore to me.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I nobly thank ye;
And may I be the same when I dishonour ye;
This I may do again. Kissing her hand.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ye may, and worthily;
Such comforts maids may grant with modesty,
And neither make her poor, nor wrong her bounty;
Noble Lisander, how fond now am I of ye?
I heard you were hurt.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: You dare not heal me lady?
I am hurt here; how sweetly now she blushes?
Excellent objects kill our sight, she blinds me;
The roses in the pride of may show pale to her;
Oh tyrant custom! and oh coward honour!
How ye compel me to put on mine own chains?
May I not kiss ye now in superstition?
For you appear a thing that I would kneel to:
Let me err that way. Kisses her.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ye shall err for once, I have a kind of noble pity on you,
Among your manly sufferings, make this most,
To err no farther in desire, for then sir,
Ye add unto the gratitudes I owe you;
And after death, your dear friends soul shall bless you.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I am wondrous honest.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I dare try. Kisses.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I have tasted a blessedness too great for dull mortality
Once more and let me die.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I dare not murder,
How will maids curse me if I kill with kisses?
And young men fly th' embraces of fair virgins?
Come pray sit down, but let's talk temperately.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Is my dear friend a-bed ?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes, and asleep;
Secure asleep, 'tis midnight too Lisander,
Speak not so loud.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: You see I am a statue,
I could not stand else as I had eaten ice,
Or took into my blood a drowsy poison,
And nature's noblest, brightest flame burn in me;
Midnight? and I stand quietly to behold so?
The alarm rung, and I sleep like a coward?
I am worn away, my faith, and dull obedience
Like crutches, carry my decayed body
Down to the grave, I have no youth within me,
Yet happily you love too.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Love with honour.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Honour? what's that? 'tis but a specious title
We should not prize too high.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Dearer than life.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: The value of it, is as time has made it,
And time and custom have too far insulted,
We are no gods, to be always tied to strictness,
'Tis a presumption to show too like 'em;
March but an hour or two under loves ensigns,
We have examples of great memories —

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: But foul ones too, that greatness cannot cover;
That wife that by example sins, sins double,
And pulls the curtain open to her shame too;
Methinks to enjoy you thus —

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: 'Tis no joy lady,
A longing bride if she stop here, would cry,
The bridegroom too, and with just cause curse Hymen;
But yield a little, be one hour a woman,
(I do not speak this to compel you lady)
And give your will but motion, let it stir
But in the taste of that weak fears call evil,
Try it to understand it, we'll do no thing,
You'll never come to know pure good else.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Fie sir.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I have found a way, let's slip into this error
As innocents, that know not what we did;
As we were dreaming both let us embrace;
The sin is none of ours then, but our fancies;
What have I said? what blasphemy to honour?
O my base thoughts! pray ye take this and shoot me.
My villain thoughts? Noise within.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I weep your misery, and would to heaven-what noise?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: It comes on louder.
Kill me, and save yourself; save your fair honour,
And lay the fault on me, let my life perish,
My base lascivious life, shoot quickly lady,

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Not for the world, retire behind the hangings,
And there stand close — my husband, close Lisander.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Dearest, are you well? Enter Cleander with a taper.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O my sad heart; my head, my head.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Alas poor soul! what do you out of your bed?
You take cold my Caliste: how do ye?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Not so well sir to lie by ye, my brother's fright —

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: I had a frightful dream too,
A very frightful dream my best Caliste:
Methought there came a dragon to your chamber,
A furious dragon (Wife) I yet shake at it:
Are all things well?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Shall I shoot him?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: No. All well sir.
'T was but your care of me, your loving care,
Which always watches.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: And methought he came
As if he had risen thus out of his den,
As I do from these hangings.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Dead.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hold good sir.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: And forced ye in his arms thus.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Twas but fancy
That troubled ye, here's nothing to disturb me,
Good sir to rest again, and I am now drowsy,
And will to bed; make no noise dear husband,
But let me sleep: before you can call anybody I am a-bed .

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: This, and sweet rest dwell with ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Come out again, and as you love Lisander,
Make haste away, you see his mind is troubled:
Do you know the door ye came at?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Well sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And can ye hit it readily?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I warrant ye;
And must I go? must here end all my happiness?
Here in a dream, as if it had no substance?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: For this time friend, or here begin our ruins;
We are both miserable.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: This is some comfort
In my afflictions; they are so full already,
They can find no increase.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Dear speak no more.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: You must be silent then.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Farewell Lisander, thou joy of man farewell.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Farewell bright lady,
Honour of womankind, a heavenly blessing.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Be ever honest.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I will be a dog else;
The virtues of your mind I'll make my library,
In which I'll study the celestial beauty:
Your constancy, my armour that I'll fight in:
And on my sword your chastity shall sit,
Terror to rebel blood.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Once more farewell:Noise within.
O that my modesty could hold you still sir, — he comes again.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Heaven keep my hand from murder,
Murder of him I love.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Away dear friend,
Down to the garden stairs, that way Lisander,
We are betrayed else. Ent. clea.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Honour guard the innocent. Exit. Lis.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Still up? I feared your health.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Has missed him happily;
I am going now ▪ I have done my meditations,
My heart's almost at peace.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: To my warm bed then.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I will pray ye lead. A pistol shot within

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: A pistol shot i'th' house?
At these hours? sure some thief, some murderer:
Rise ho, rise all, I am betrayed.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O fortune!
O giddy thing! he has met some opposition,
And killed; I am confounded, lost for ever. Enter Dorilaus

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Thieves, my noble father, villains, and rogues.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Indeed, I heard a pistol, let's search about.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To bed again, they are gone sir,
I will not bid you thank my valour for't;
Gone at the garden door; there were a dozen,
And bravely armed, I saw 'em.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: I am glad, glad at the heart.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: One shot at me, and missed me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No, 'twas at me, the bullet flew close by me,
Close by my ear; another had a huge sword,
Flourished it thus; but at the point I met him,
But the rogue taking me to be your lordship,
(As sure your name is terrible, and we
Not much unlike in the dark) roared out aloud,
'Tis the kill cow Dorilaus, and away
They ran as they had flown: now you must love me,
Or fear me for my courage wench.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: O rogue?
O lying rogue, Lisander stumbled madam,
At the stair's head, and in the fall the shot went off;
Was gone before they rose.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I thank heaven for't.

sp.speaker: Clari.
sp.l: I was frighted too, it spoiled my game with Leon.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You must sit up; and they had come to your chamber
What pranks would they have played: how came the door open?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I heard 'em when they forced it; up I rose,
Took Durindana in my hand; and like
Orlando, issued forth.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: I know you are valiant.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: To bed again.
And be you henceforth provident, at sunrising
We must part for a while.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: When you are a-bed ,
Take leave of her, there 'twill be worth the taking;
Here 'tis but a cold ceremony, ere long
We'll find Lisander, or we have ill fortune.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Lock all the doors fast.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Though they all stood open,
My name writ on the door, they dare not enter. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Claran, Friar with a letter.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: Turned hermit?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Yes, and a devout one too: I heard him preach.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: That lessens my belief,
For though I grant my Lydian a scholar
As far as fits a gentleman, he hath studied
Humanity, and in that he is a master;
Civility of manners, courtship, arms;
But never aimed at (As I could perceive)
The deep points of divinity.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: That confirms his
Devotion to be real, no way tainted
With ostentation, or hypocrisy,
The cankers of religion; his sermon
So full of gravity and with such sweetness
Delivered, that it drew the admiration
Of all the hearers on him; his own letters
To you, which witness he will leave the world,
And these to fair Olinda, his late mistress,
In which he hath with all the moving language
That ever expressed rhetoric, solicited
The lady to forget him, and make you
Blessed in her embraces, may remove
All scrupulous doubts.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: It strikes a sadness in me,
I know not what to think of't.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Ere he entered
His solitary cell, he penned a ditty,
His long and last farewell to love, and women,
So feelingly, that I confess however
It stands not with my order to be taken
With such poetical raptures; I was moved,
And strangely with it.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: Have you the copy?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Yes sir:
My novice too can sing it, if you please
To give him hearing.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: And it will come timely,
For I am full of melancholy thoughts,
Against which I have heard with reason music
To be the speediest cure, pray you apply it.
Adieu fond love farewell you wanton powers,
I am free again;
Thou dull disease of blood and idle hours.
Bewitching pain,
Fly to the fools that sigh away their time.
My nobler love to heaven clime,
And there behold beauty still young,
That time can never corrupt, nor death destroy;
Immortal sweetness by fair angels sung,
And honoured by eternity and joy:
There lives my love, thither my hopes aspire;
Fond love declines, this heavenly love grows higher.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: How do ye approve it?

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: To its due desert,
It is a heavenly hymn, no ditty father,
It passes through my ears unto my soul,
And works divinely on it; give me leave
A little to consider; shall I be
Out done in all things? nor good of myself.
Nor by example? shall my loose hopes still,
The viands of a fond affection, feed me
As I were a sensual beast, spiritual food
Refused by my sick palate? 'tis resolved.
How far off father, doth this new made hermit
Make his abode?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Some two days' journey son.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: Having revealed my fair intentions to ye,
I hope your piety will not deny me
Your aides to further 'em?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: That were against a good man's charity.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: My first request is,
You would some time, for reasons I will show you,
Defer delivery of Lidian's letters
To fair Olinda.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: For what follows,
You shall direct me; something I will do,
A new born zeal, and friendship prompts me to. Ex.

div.stage: Enter Dorilaus, Cleander, Chamberlaine, table, tapers, and three stools.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: We have supped well friend; let our beds be ready,
We must be stirring early,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: They are made sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I cannot sleep yet, where's the jovial host
You told me of? 'thas been my custom ever
To parley with mine host.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: He's a good fellow,
And such a one I know you love to laugh with;
Go call your master up.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: He cannot come sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Is he a-bed with his wife?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: No certainly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Or with some other guests?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Neither and 't like ye.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Why then he shall come by your leave my friend,
I'll fetch him up myself.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Indeed you'll fail sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Is he i'th' house?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: No, but he is hard by sir;
He is fast in's grave, he has been dead these three weeks.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then of my conscience he will come but lamely,
And discourse worse.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Farewell mine honest host then,
Mine honest merry host; will you to bed yet?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No, not this hour, I prithee sit and chat by me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Give us a quart of wine then, we'll be merry.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A match my son; pray let your wine be living,
Or lay it by your master.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: It shall be quick sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Has not mine host a wife?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: A good old woman.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Another coffin, that is not so handsome;
Your hostesses in inns should be blithe things,
Pretty, and young to draw in passengers;
She'll never fill her beds well, if she be not beauteous.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: And courteous too. Enter chamberlain with wine.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Ay, ay, and a good fellow,
That will mistake sometimes a gentleman
For her good man; well done; here's to Lisander.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: My full love meets it; make fire in our lodgings,
We'll trouble thee no farther; to your son. Ex. cham.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Put in Clarange too; off with't, I thank ye;
This wine drinks merrier still, oh for mine host now,
Were he alive again, and well disposed,
I would so claw his pate.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: You're a hard drinker.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I love to make mine host drunk, he will lie then
The rarest, and the roundest, of his friends,
His quarrels, and his guests, and they are the best bawds too
Take 'em in that tune.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: You know all.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I did son, but time, and arms have worn me out

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.p: 'Tis late sir, I hear none stirring. A lute is struck.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Hark, what's that, a lute?
'Tis at the door I think.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: The doors are shut fast.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: 'Tis morning sure, the fiddlers are got up
To fright men's sleeps, have we never a pisspot ready?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Now I remember, I have heard mine host that's dead,
Touch a lute rarely, and as rarely sing too,
A brave still mean.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I would give a brace of French crowns
To see him rise and fiddle.
'Tis late and cold, stir up the fire;
Sit close, and draw the table nigher;
Be merry, and drink wine that's old,
A hearty medicine 'gainst a cold.
Your beds of want on down the best,
Where you shall tumble to your rest;
I could wish you wenches too,
But I am dead and cannot do;
Call for the best the house may ring,
Sack, white, and claret let them bring,
And drink apace while breath you have,
You'll find but cold drink in the grave;
Plover, Partridge for your dinner,
And a capon for the sinner,
You shall find ready when you are up,
And your horse shall have his sup:
Welcome shall fly round,
And I shall smile though under ground.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Hark, a song, now as I live, it is his voice.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: He sings well, the devil has a pleasant pipe.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: The fellow lied sure,Enter host.
He is not dead, he's here: how pale he looks?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Is this he?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: You are welcome noble gentlemen,
My brave old guest most welcome.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Lying knaves,
To tell us you were dead, come sit down by us,
We thank ye for your song.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Would 't had been better.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Speak, are ye dead?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Yes indeed am I gentlemen,
I have been dead these three weeks.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then here's to ye, to comfort your cold body.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: What do ye mean? stand further off.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I will stand nearer to him,
Shall he come out on's coffin to bear us company,
And we not bid him welcome? come mine host,
Mine honest host, here's to ye.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Spirit's sir, drink not?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Why do ye appear?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: To wait upon ye gentlemen,
'Thas been my duty living, now my farewell;
I fear ye are not used accordingly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I could wish you warmer company mine host,
However we are used?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Next to entreat a courtesy,
And then I go to peace.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Is't in our power?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Yes and 'tis this, to see my body buried
In holy ground, for now I lie unhallowed,
By the clerks fault; let my new grave be made
Amongst good fellows, that have died before me,
And merry hosts of my kind.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And forty stoops of wine drank at thy funeral.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Do you know our travel?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Yes, to seek your friends,
That in afflictions wander now.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Seek 'em no farther, but be confident
They shall return in peace.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: There's comfort yet.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Pray ye one word more, is't in your power mine host,
Answer me softly, some hours before my death,
To give me warning?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I cannot tell ye truly,
But if I can, so much alive I loved ye,
I will appear again, adieu. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Adieu sir.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I am troubled; these strange apparitions are
For the most part fatal.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: This if told, will not
Find credit, the light breaks a pace, let's lie down
And take some little rest, an hour or two,
Then do mine hosts desire, and so return,
I do believe him.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: So do I, to rest sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Clarinda?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Is the house well ordered?
The doors looked to now in your master's absence?
Your care, and diligence amongst the servants?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: I am stirring madam.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: So thou art Clarinda,
More than thou ought'st I am sure, why dost thou blush?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: I do not blush.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why dost thou hang thy head wench?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Madam, ye are deceived, I look upright,
I understand ye not: she has spied Leon,Aside.
Shame of his want of caution.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Look on me; what, blush again?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: 'Tis more than I know madam;
I have no cause that I find yet.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Examine then.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Your ladyship is set I think to shame me.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Do not deserve't. who lay with you last night?
What bedfellow had ye? none of the maids came near ye.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Madam they did.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Twas one in your cousin's clothes then,
And wore a sword; and sure I keep no Amazons;
Wench do not lie, 'twill but proclaim thee guilty;
Lies hide our sins like nets; like perspectives,
They draw offences nearer still, and greater:
Come tell the truth.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: You are the strangest lady
To have these doubts of me; how have I lived madam?
And which of all my careful services deserves these shames?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Leave facing? 'twill not serve ye,
This impudence becomes thee worse than lying?
I thought ye had lived well, and I was proud of't ▪
But you are pleased to abuse my thoughts; who was't?
Honest repentance yet will make the fault less.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Do ye compel me? do you stand so strict too?
Nay, then have at ye; I shall rub that sore madam ▪
(Since ye provoke me) will but vex your ladyship;
Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I will know.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: For your own peace,
The peace of your own conscience ask no farther;
Walk in, and let me alone.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: No, I will know all.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Why, then I'll tell ye, 't was a man I lay with,
Never admire, 'tis easy to be done, madam,
And usual too, a proper man I lay with;
Why should you vex at that? young as Lisander,
And able too; I grudge not at your pleasure,
Why should you stir at mine? I steal none from ye,

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And dost thou glory in this sin?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.p: I am glad on't, to glory in't is for a mighty lady that may command.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why didst thou name Lisander?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Does it anger ye? does it a little gall ye?
